content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a tough time sleeping lately. There’s just so much on my mind, especially about work. I’m scared I might lose my job, and I don’t know what I’d do if that happened. It’s starting to feel like I can’t shut my brain off at night.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like there's quite a lot weighing on you right now with everything going on at work. Struggling with sleep can be really exhausting—especially when your mind feels so busy. How has this been affecting other parts of your life?

Honestly, it’s been hard. I feel tired and irritable during the day, and I’m having trouble focusing at work, which only makes me more worried about losing my job. I try to hold it together for my kids and my partner, but it just feels overwhelming sometimes.

That sounds like a heavy load to carry, especially while trying to be there for your loved ones. It's clear you're doing your best, but feeling overwhelmed and tired can make everything feel harder. What have you noticed helps, even a little, when things start to feel this way?

I haven’t really found much that helps, to be honest. I’ve tried watching TV before bed to distract myself or scrolling on my phone, but it just makes me stay up even later. Sometimes I talk to my partner about how I’m feeling, and that helps a tiny bit, but I still feel stuck most of the time.

It sounds like you’ve been searching for ways to cope and trying different things, even though it hasn’t fully eased the struggle yet. Talking with your partner seems to bring a little relief, which shows how much you value connecting and sharing. What do you think makes it feel harder to find something that works for you right now?

I think it’s just that the stress feels constant. Even when I try to relax, my brain keeps going back to all the "what-ifs" about work and money. It’s hard to see a way out of it, so I just end up feeling stuck in this cycle.

That persistent stress and fear of “what-ifs” sounds exhausting and hard to escape—it’s like your mind won’t let go even when you try to take a break. A constant cycle like that can feel overwhelming, especially without an obvious way out. What would life look like if you could step out of that cycle, even for a little while?

Honestly, if I could just stop overthinking and get some proper sleep, that would feel like such a relief. I’d probably feel more focused at work and less irritable with my family. Just having some peace of mind would make everything feel a bit more manageable, you know?

Absolutely, finding that peace of mind and being able to rest sounds like it could bring a lot of relief and help you reconnect with the things that matter most—your focus at work and your time with your family. It sounds like you’re recognizing what you really want: some calm and clarity. What do you think might be a small first step toward finding that?

Honestly, I’m not sure what that first step would look like. I guess trying to find a way to let go of these thoughts before bed would help, but I don’t even know where to start with that. It feels easier said than done.

It makes sense that letting go of those thoughts feels easier said than done—especially when they’ve been so overwhelming. Starting with even small steps can feel difficult when the stress is constant and so many things are on your mind. Would it be helpful to explore those ideas together, or is there something else you feel would support you in the moment?

It’s hard to even know where to begin when everything feels like so much, but yeah, maybe talking through ideas could help. I just want to figure out how to stop this cycle so I can feel like myself again.

It’s brave of you to want to face this cycle head-on, even when everything feels like a lot. It shows your determination to find some relief and feel more like yourself again. Is there anything else you want to share or explore before we look at ideas?
I think that’s all for now. I’m ready to hear some ideas if you’ve got any. I really need to find a way to get out of this.

Thank you for sharing everything—you’ve offered a lot about your experiences and what’s important to you. It sounds like you're ready to take steps toward finding relief and better sleep. Before diving in, here’s a quick summary: you've been feeling overwhelmed with constant stress about work, which impacts your sleep and daily life. You’ve tried a few things to relax but haven’t felt much progress. You want to stop the overthinking cycle to get some rest and focus better at work while being present for your family. Does that capture things accurately? 

If so, would you like to discuss ideas together now?

Thank you for sharing everything—you’ve offered a lot about your experiences and what’s important to you. It sounds like you're ready to take steps toward finding relief and better sleep. Before diving in, here’s a quick summary: you've been feeling overwhelmed with constant stress about work, which impacts your sleep and daily life. You’ve tried a few things to relax but haven’t felt much progress. You want to stop the overthinking cycle to get some rest and focus better at work while being present for your family. Does that capture things accurately? 

If so, would you like to discuss ideas together now?

It seems like that summary reflects your current situation, and your desire to move forward is clear. Let's explore some ideas together—are there any particular areas you'd like to start with, or should we focus on ways to quiet the mind before bedtime?
Yeah, that sums it up well. I think focusing on quieting my mind before bed would be a good place to start since sleep seems to be the biggest issue right now. Do you have any suggestions for that?

Great to hear you're ready to focus on quieting your mind before bed. Would you like to reflect on sleep data together? If you've tracked things like sleep duration recently, it might provide clues about patterns or changes that could help with this goal. Let me know if you'd be open to that, or if you'd prefer to focus directly on strategies without reviewing sleep data.
